fusion","norm_name":"folklore-fusion","isloc":false,"loc_id":null}],"audio_stream_url":null},{"story_id":184909,"story_date":1751549462,"slug":"the-worm-pantilde-review","description":"The Cornish avant-folk musician and performance artist pays fantastical tribute to the humble worm.","full_text":"Like several species of birds and those wild, wild horses, the humble worm has inspired plenty of fascinating music over the years. There’s “Doctor Worm” by They Might Be Giants, for instance, whose titular character can somehow play the drums. The Ohio Players had their “Funky Worm” who only came out of the ground “when he wants to get down.” Other worms have had darker metaphorical purposes, such as those that writhed into Roger Waters’s troubled psyche during Pink Floyd’s The Wall.

For the avant-folk musician and performance artist Amy Lawrence, who also happens to be a gardener, the worm tends to be considered a “small, insignificant, and low creature.” Those are its contemporary cultural connotations, at least. There are worms from mythology, to which Lawrence is equally drawn, which were powerful and terrifying beings, like serpents and dragons. On that note, those massive ones from the sci-fi series Dune also spring to mind.

Lawrence doesn’t exactly reconcile the contrasting characteristics of this bilateral muse but rather combines, plays with, and channels its dichotomies into performances and recordings as The Worm. The project’s latest transmission from the soil, “Pantilde”, is set in an imagined and fantastical equivalent of the Cornish countryside where it is required, as expressed early in the record, to pass “through some kind of portal made of birds.” In this place, grass grows on toes and noses as well as on the landscape. That is, unless certain songs are sung from the perspective of the terrain, which certainly could be the case.

The title track concerns a presumably human handyperson traveling from place to place on their beloved donkey. Another mysterious and more otherworldly voyage takes place on “Journey,” the song’s style suggesting an English Björk fronting an isolated cello track from This Mortal Coil. Harps, recorders, other stringed or tubular instruments, and occasional percussion are used elsewhere as sparsely delicate accompaniment to The Worm’s usually time-unspecific tales. A number of these suggest an ancient past, whereas others hint towards a ramshackle future akin to that imagined and explored by Richard Dawson on 2022’s The Ruby Cord. Pastoral instrumentals such as “Through Greeness” and “Gust” sit aside the narrative pieces, some of which are more decipherable or straightforwardly interpretable than others.

“If we understand the worm, we understand life,” as the saying goes, courtesy of the Nobel Prize-winning biologist John Sulston. This enlightenment could take some time, however. The remainder of Sir Sulston’s quotation is sometimes left off. It reads: “…Which of course, we’re nowhere near.” It’s time to listen more closely.

–JR Moores","title":"The Worm, ","full_text":"On the cover of her self-titled sixth album, released in 2021, singer-songwriter Laura Stevenson is shown reclining on her couch with her newborn daughter, a half-awake dog on guard at her feet, her favorite records hanging on the wall behind her. Stevenson called this snapshot (a painting of a photo) “the most me I’ve ever felt.” Four years on, things have changed.

“Late Great” surveys the blow-up and clean- up of Stevenson’s 17-year relationship with her husband, co-parent, and bandmate—the guy who encouraged the young keyboardist of ska-punk ensemble Bomb the Music Industry! to record the not-very-punk songs she’d been writing on the side, the ones that would become 2010’s A Record. “It all starts and ends here/ My late great,” Stevenson warbles to herself on the epic title track, her voice breathtaking as always. Her personal pain is relatable, too, whether she’s softly seething at being a man’s “source of an ordinary life/ Virgin mother” or admitting she’s trapped in the still-kidding-yourself stage where “all I can muster is, ‘Baby, you’re the one.’” On the piano-only “Middle Love,” the record’s smallest, most voyeuristic song, Stevenson details the agonizing moment divorce papers are signed; her anxiety is palpable as she ruminates on whether she’ll even make it to the car.

She does, of course, as reflected by the cautious joy underpinning many of the album’s tracks. The most cocksure song is “Can I Fly Free?,” a stabilizing sugar rush tracked with what Stevenson refers to in the press release as “millions of guitars,” zigzagging like bees in a hive. It’s almost an anomaly, given that arrangements elsewhere are less Liz Phair and more Waxahatchee-does-Sufjan-Stevens with plump brass and rays of pedal steel. She’s also softened her usually brutal self-deprecation, bedding down in grief on rainy, under-the-covers cuts like “Short and Sweet,” not cursing herself but healing slowly. “I’ll be just fine/ I want to be under a little while longer,” she murmurs, answered by drowsy fuzz guitar. The self-love peaks on “#1 (2),” a peaceful little reprise of the album opener. Over a sparsely stroked guitar, Stevenson half-whispers the same lyrics as “#1,” or starts to: a funereal French horn interlude interrupts, nudging her towards quiet, exhausted liberation instead. She’s no longer fearfully bracing for the end of the relationship (as on “#1”)—she’s made it through to the other side. The lyric “I want to…” becomes “I, one, two.” Laura Stevenson, take two.

–Hayden Merrick","title":"Laura Stevenson, “Late
